sites.name: Château des Ducs de Bretagne
sites.description: This impressive castle-turned-museum was the residence of the Dukes of Brittany between the 13th and 16th centuries and later a royal French castle. The restored monument now houses the Nantes History Museum with interactive exhibitions exploring the city's past, including its maritime trade and controversial slave trade history.
sites.seasonal_notes: The courtyard is free to access year-round. Summer features evening light shows projected onto the castle walls. Gardens are particularly beautiful in spring.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for the courtyard. Museum tickets can be purchased onsite or online. Free entry to the museum on the first Sunday of each month.

sites.name: Les Machines de l'île
sites.description: A unique artistic project located in the former shipyards, featuring giant mechanical animals and fantastic machines inspired by the works of Jules Verne and Leonardo da Vinci. The centerpiece is the Grand Elephant, a 12-meter high mechanical elephant that visitors can ride as it sprays water from its trunk.
sites.seasonal_notes: Very busy during summer months and school holidays. Winter has shorter operating hours but smaller crowds. The Carousel of Marine Worlds is covered and operates year-round.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking highly recommended, especially for elephant rides. Combined tickets available for all attractions.

sites.name: Cathédrale Saint-Pierre-et-Saint-Paul
sites.description: This impressive Gothic cathedral took over 450 years to complete (from 1434 to 1891) and features a strikingly bright white limestone exterior. Inside, visitors can find the ornate tomb of Francis II, Duke of Brittany, and spectacular stained glass windows. The cathedral's twin towers rise 63 meters above the city.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful lighting in mornings when sun shines through the stained glass. Special religious services during Easter and Christmas.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Respect quiet during services. Periodic closing during weddings or religious ceremonies.

sites.name: Jardin des Plantes
sites.description: One of the most important botanical gardens in France, featuring 7 hectares of greenery, rare plant collections, and themed gardens. Created in 1807, it houses over 10,000 plant species, magnificent greenhouses, and artistic topiary installations. The garden is also known for its whimsical giant bench installations.
sites.seasonal_notes: Spring brings magnificent blooms and summer features outdoor exhibitions. The greenhouses offer tropical plant viewing during colder months.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free guided tours available on weekends during summer (check schedules).

sites.name: Passage Pommeraye
sites.description: This ornate three-level shopping arcade built between 1840-1843 is considered one of the most beautiful in Europe. With its Renaissance-inspired staircases, sculptures, and glass roof, the passage connects Rue Crébillon with Rue Santeuil and houses boutique shops, cafés, and art galleries.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautifully decorated during Christmas. Air-conditioned refuge during summer heat. Most shops close on Sundays.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Best explored during shopping hours (10am-7pm most days).

sites.name: Musée d'Arts de Nantes
sites.description: Recently renovated and expanded, this fine arts museum houses an impressive collection spanning from the 13th century to contemporary works. The museum features paintings by Kandinsky, Monet, Picasso, Delacroix, and Chagall, along with rotating temporary exhibitions in a beautiful architectural setting combining historic and modern buildings.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with special exhibitions rotating seasonally. Less crowded on weekday afternoons. Air-conditioned in summer.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required for general admission. Guided tours available with additional fee. Free entry on first Sunday of each month.

sites.name: Île de Nantes
sites.description: This island in the Loire River is the center of Nantes' urban renewal, transforming former shipyards into cultural and artistic spaces. Home to Les Machines de l'île, numerous public art installations, trendy restaurants, and the creative quarter, it represents the city's innovative spirit and future vision.
sites.seasonal_notes: Summer brings outdoor events, concerts, and food markets. The Hangar à Bananes area is particularly lively on weekend evenings year-round.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for exploring. Bike rentals available for exploring the island's cycling paths.

sites.name: Tour Bretagne
sites.description: This 37-story office tower (built 1972-1976) is the tallest building in Nantes. The 'Le Nid' (The Nest) bar and observation deck on the 32nd floor offers 360-degree panoramic views of the city. The space features a giant white bird sculpture by artist Jean Jullien, with its body serving as the bar counter.
sites.seasonal_notes: Sunset visits offer spectacular views. Open year-round but can close during severe weather. The observation deck is particularly popular on clear days.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Small entrance fee for the observation deck (free with Nantes Pass). Expect queues on weekends and holidays.

sites.name: Memorial to the Abolition of Slavery
sites.description: Located along the Loire River, this powerful memorial is one of the largest in the world dedicated to the abolition of slavery. The underground passageway features illuminated text in multiple languages, commemorating Nantes' historical role in the slave trade while celebrating the universal struggle for human rights.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. The riverside location is particularly pleasant in spring and summer. Occasional special commemorations held on May 10 (National Day of Remembrance of the Slave Trade).
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free guided tours sometimes available through Nantes Tourism Office.

sites.name: Musée Jules Verne
sites.description: Dedicated to Nantes' famous literary son, this museum is housed in a 19th-century building overlooking the Loire. It features original manuscripts, first edition books, models of the inventions described in Verne's novels, and personal artifacts that provide insight into the author's imagination and scientific vision.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round except Tuesdays. The small museum can get crowded during summer tourist season and school holidays.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Audio guides available in multiple languages.

sites.name: Talensac Market
sites.description: Nantes' largest and most important daily market offers an authentic slice of local life with over 100 vendors selling fresh produce, seafood, cheeses, baked goods, flowers, and regional specialties. The covered market hall dates from the 1930s and is surrounded by open-air stalls.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open daily (except Mondays) from 8am-1pm. Sunday mornings are especially lively but crowded. The market showcases seasonal local produce throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Come early for the best selection and fewer crowds. Bring cash as some vendors don't accept cards.

sites.name: Le Voyage à Nantes
sites.description: This urban art trail marked by a green line painted on the pavement leads visitors through the city to discover permanent and temporary art installations, historic sites, and hidden gems. The project transforms Nantes into an open-air museum, with new works added each summer.
sites.seasonal_notes: The full trail with temporary installations is active during summer (July-August). Many permanent works can be seen year-round. Special winter itinerary available in December-January.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free maps available at tourism office or downloadable app with audio guide.

sites.name: Trentemoult
sites.description: This colorful former fishing village across the Loire River from Nantes has transformed into a quirky, artistic neighborhood with narrow streets, brightly painted houses, and riverside restaurants. Now accessible by regular ferry service, it offers excellent views of Nantes and a relaxed, bohemian atmosphere.
sites.seasonal_notes: Riverside restaurants are especially pleasant in summer. The village is particularly photogenic in good weather. December features a unique floating Christmas market.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for exploring. Navibus ferry runs regularly from central Nantes (small fee or included with transport pass).

sites.name: Place Graslin
sites.description: This elegant neoclassical square is one of Nantes' most beautiful public spaces, dominated by the Grand Théâtre (opera house) and surrounded by handsome 18th-century buildings. The square features the famous La Cigale brasserie, outdoor cafés, and connects to the upscale shopping street Rue Crébillon.
sites.seasonal_notes: Lively throughout the year. Summer evenings feature outdoor dining. The square is beautifully decorated during Christmas season.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for the square. Advance reservations recommended for dining at La Cigale or attending performances at the theater.

sites.name: La Cigale
sites.description: Opening in 1895, this iconic Art Nouveau brasserie is considered one of the most beautiful in France with its ornate ceiling, ceramic decorations, and stained glass. Located on Place Graslin, it has hosted artists, writers, and celebrities while serving traditional French cuisine and seafood specialties.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Famous for oysters during winter months. Busy for weekend brunch throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: Advance reservation strongly recommended, especially for dinner and weekends. The historic interior makes this worth visiting even for just coffee or drinks.

sites.name: Église Sainte-Croix
sites.description: This Baroque church features an unusual astronomical clock on its bell tower that has been keeping time since 1849. The interior includes a pipe organ dating from 1755, while the bell tower clock displays the time, date, moon phases, and high tide times in cities along France's Atlantic coast.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. The clock is illuminated at night. Occasional organ concerts throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. The clock mechanism can be viewed during limited hours - check tourist information for current schedule.

sites.name: Parc de Procé
sites.description: This English-style landscaped park covers 12 hectares in western Nantes and features magnificent old trees, meandering streams, an ornamental pond, rose garden, and historic manor house. Less touristic than central parks, it offers a peaceful retreat favored by local residents.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful in spring with flowering trees and roses. Autumn brings spectacular foliage colors. The expansive lawns are popular for picnics in summer.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free access at all times. The manor house hosts occasional exhibitions.

sites.name: Hangar à Bananes
sites.description: Once used to store bananas imported from Africa and the Caribbean, this renovated warehouse on the western tip of Île de Nantes now houses restaurants, bars, nightclubs, and exhibition spaces. The area comes alive at night and offers great views of the Loire River.
sites.seasonal_notes: Particularly lively on summer evenings when outdoor terraces are open. Many venues have reduced hours in winter. Special events and festivals throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for general access. Reservations recommended for restaurants, especially on weekends.

sites.name: La Maison des Hommes et des Techniques
sites.description: Located in the former Nantes shipyard buildings, this museum preserves the industrial and labor history of the city's shipbuilding industry that once employed thousands. Through photographs, models, and personal accounts, it tells the story of the workers and techniques that made Nantes a major maritime construction center.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round except Mondays. The museum hosts temporary exhibitions related to maritime history and worker movements.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free guided tours available on weekend afternoons (check schedule).

sites.name: LU Tower (Le Lieu Unique)
sites.description: The former LU biscuit factory (famous for Petit Beurre cookies) has been transformed into a thriving cultural center while preserving its distinctive tower. Now called 'Le Lieu Unique,' it houses a theater, exhibition spaces, restaurant, bookstore, hammam, and hosts concerts and performances with an avant-garde focus.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with seasonal programming. The summer terrace along the canal is particularly pleasant. Many special events and festivals throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking recommended for performances and events. The bar and restaurant are open to all without reservations.

sites.name: Passage Sainte-Croix
sites.description: This restored medieval passage in the heart of the historic center has been transformed into a cultural and spiritual venue hosting exhibitions, concerts, and discussions. The courtyard features a magnificent 19th-century magnolia tree and provides a tranquil space away from the busy streets.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with rotating exhibitions. The courtyard is especially beautiful when the magnolia blooms in spring.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for general access. Check program for special events and exhibitions.
